title: Respect the Blade
body:
Knives are the most common tool in the kitchen and a frequent cause of accidents. Cuts can range from minor nicks to severed tendons.

**Golden Rule:** A sharp knife is safer than a blunt one. Blunt knives require more force, increasing the chance of slipping.

title: Safe Handling
body:
- **Carry safely:** Point the blade down and keep it close to your side. Never run with a knife.
- **Passing:** Place the knife on a flat surface for the other person to pick up. Don't hand it over blade-first.
- **Falling knives:** NEVER try to catch a falling knife. Step back and let it fall.

title: Storage and Cleaning
body:
- **Storage:** Use a knife block, magnetic rack, or sheath. Never leave loose knives in a drawer.
- **Cleaning:** Wash knives immediately by hand. NEVER leave a knife in a sink full of soapy waterâ€”the next person won't see it.

stem: You drop your knife. What do you do?
options: Try to catch it by the handle
Try to catch it by the blade
Step back and let it fall
rationale: A falling knife has no handle. Stepping back protects your feet and hands.

title: Module Complete
body: You've sharpened your knowledge on knife safety. Keep them sharp, store them right, and respect the blade.
